facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 205 of 1966 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 205 of 1966. Appeal from the judgment and order dated May 28, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Income Tax Reference No. 79 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated May 28, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Income Tax Reference No. 79 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated May 28, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Income Tax Reference No. 79 of 1959. Veda Vyasa, A. N. Kirpal, S. P. Nayyar and R. N. Sachthey, for the appellants.

facts.text: Appeal in pursuance of a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court under s. 66A(2) of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal in pursuance of a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta under s. 66  A  2  of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922, is directed against the judgment of the High Court in Income Tax Reference No. 79 of 1959.

facts.text: High Court answered the question referred by the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal against the Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment, the High Court answered the following question, referred to it by the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, against the Revenue Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the appeal before the Appellate Tribunal was filed by a proper person ?

facts.text: The question referred: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the appeal before the Appellate Tribunal was filed by a proper person?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the appeal before the Appellate Tribunal was filed by a proper person ? The relevant facts are stated in the statement of the case and are as follows The respondents, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, is a Hindu Undivided family

facts.text: Respondents (assessee) is a Hindu Undivided Family.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, is a Hindu Undivided family and for the assessment year 1947-48 the assessment was made by the Income Tax Officer, Dist. 1 2  on February 12, 1952.

facts.text: Assessment year 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: and for the assessment year 1947-48 the assessment was made by the Income Tax Officer, Dist. 1 2  on February 12, 1952. facts.text: Assessment made by Income Tax Officer, District 1(2) on February 12, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: the assessment was made by the Income Tax Officer, Dist. 1 2  on February 12, 1952. He held that the income of Rs. 1,41,851/- derived from forests in East Pakistan was number agricultural income exempt from tax under the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Income of Rs. 1,41,851 derived from forests in East Pakistan held as non-agricultural income exempt from tax by ITO.

anchor.surface_text: He held that the income of Rs. 1,41,851/- derived from forests in East Pakistan was number agricultural income exempt from tax under the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922. The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who, by his order dated February 7, 1956, held that the said amount of Rs. 1,41,851/- represented income from agriculture and was thus exempt from tax.

facts.text: ITO held the income as agricultural income exempt from tax.

anchor.surface_text: He held that the income of Rs. 1,41,851/- derived from forests in East Pakistan was number agricultural income exempt from tax under the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary objection was raised before the Appellate Tribunal, on behalf of the assessee, that the appeal was incompetent because it had been filed by the Income Tax Officer, District VI, Calcutta, and number by the Income Tax Officer, District 1 2 , Calcutta. It was companytended before the Ap- pellate Tribunal that the Income Tax Officer, District 1 2 , was the proper officer to file the appeal because he had made the assessment.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected the contention, held ITO Dist VI competent under s.64(2).

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal rejected the companytention. It held The representative of the assessee companyceded that the assessee was formerly residing at 24 and 25, Beadon Row, Calcutta but in 1954 he shifted to 29/B Ballygunge Circular Road, Calcutta, which is within the jurisdiction of 5Sup Cl/67-8 the Income-tax Officer, District VI, Calcutta.

facts.text: No mention of any order of transfer from ITO Dist 1(2) to Dist VI by Commissioner or Board.

anchor.surface_text: It will be numbericed that in the facts given in the statement of the case and the reasoning of the Appellate Tribunal there is numbermention of any order of transfer having been passed by the Commissioner of Income Tax or the Board of Revenue transferring the files from the Income Tax Officer, District 1 2  to the Income Tax Officer, District VI, Calcutta.

facts.text: No mention of which Commissioner directed ITO Dist VI to file the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Neither is there any mention which Commissioner of Income Tax directed the Income Tax Officer, District VI, Calcutta, to file the appeal.

facts.text: High Court observed original assessment by ITO Dist 1(2) subordinate to Commissioner of Income-tax, Calcutta.

facts.text: High Court held no transfer by Board under s.5(7A), so ITO Dist 1(2) remained in seisin.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the Commissioner of Income Tax, Calcutta, companyld number transfer the case or the file to the Income-tax Officer, District VI, Calcutta. It is only the Board of Revenue which companyld transfer the case under section 5 7  a . There was numbersuch transfer by the Board of Revenue.

facts.text: Supreme Court ignores certain facts found by High Court: no transfer by Board, subordinations, no transfer to Dist VI.

anchor.surface_text: We will, for the purpose of this appeal, ignore the following facts found by the High Court  1  that there was numbertransfer of the case by the Board of Revenue  2  that the Income Tax Officer, District 1  2  was an officer subordi- nate to the Commissioner of Income Tax, Calcutta  3  that the Income Tax Officer, District VI, was an officer subordinate to the Commissioner of West Bengal and  4  that there was numbertransfer of the case or the file to the Income Tax Officer, District VI, who was the appropriate officer for the Ballygunge Circular Road area.

facts.text: Direction by Commissioner to ITO Dist VI to file appeal is not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the direc- 32 5 tion of the Commissioner is companycerned, it is number disputed before us that a direction for filing the appeal was given to the Income-tax Officer, District VI but numberorder of transfer under section 5 5  read with section 5 7  a  companyld be shown to us, although the original records were brought into Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that under s.33(2), Commissioner directs 'the Income Tax Officer' who has jurisdiction over assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the expression denotes an Income Tax Officer having jurisdiction over the assessee or the matter. In other words, the officer selected must have some companycern with the assessee against whom the appeal is filed by the Commissioner of Income Tax.

facts.text: By 1954, assessee changed residence to area under ITO Dist VI jurisdiction per s.64(2).

anchor.surface_text: We have already mentioned that the assessee changed his residence to 29B, Ballygunge Circular Road, Calcutta, in 1954. By the time the appeal came to be filed, the Income Tax Officer, District VI, had jurisdiction over him.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the appeal before the Appellate Tribunal was filed by a proper person?

issues.text: Whether the Income Tax Officer, District VI, Calcutta, was the proper officer to file the appeal

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary objection was raised before the Appellate Tribunal, on behalf of the assessee, that the appeal was incompetent because it had been filed by the Income Tax Officer, District VI, Calcutta, and not by the Income Tax Officer, District 1 2 , Calcutta. It was contended before the Ap- pellate Tribunal that the Income Tax Officer, District 1 2 , was the proper officer to file the appeal because he had made the assessment.

arguments.claim: The appeal before the Appellate Tribunal was incompetent because it was filed by the Income Tax Officer, District VI, Calcutta, and not by the Income Tax Officer, District 1(2), Calcutta who made the assessment.

arguments.claim: The Income Tax Officer, District VI, had jurisdiction under section 64(2) due to the assessee's shift in residence, so the appeal was competent.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal rejected the companytention. It held The representative of the assessee companyceded that the assessee was formerly residing at 24 and 25, Beadon Row, Calcutta but in 1954 he shifted to 29/B Ballygunge Circular Road, Calcutta, which is within the jurisdiction of 5Sup Cl/67-8 the Income-tax Officer, District VI, Calcutta. Therefore, the jurisdiction for assessment vested in the Incometax Officer, District VI in view of the provision of section 64 2  of the Income-tax Act.

The learned companynsel urges that the High Court had numberjurisdiction to send for records or look into them, and the whole judgment of the High Court is based on new facts stated by it in the penultimate para of its judgment.

There was numbertransfer of the case or of the file to the Income-tax Officer, District VI, who was the appropriate officer in the Ballygunge Circular Road area. Therefore, it cannot be said that the Income-tax Officer, District VI ever came to be in seisin of the case or the file.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court ignored this fact found by High Court.

arguments.claim: Under s.33(2), 'the Income Tax Officer' means one having jurisdiction over assessee or matter, not any ITO; performs ministerial act.

anchor.surface_text: The answer to the question depends on the interpretation of s. 33 2  read with s. 64 2 . Section 33 2  provides that the Commissioner may, if he objects to any order passed by an Appellate Assistant Commissioner under section 3 1, direct the Income-tax Officer to appeal to the Appellate Tribunal against such order, and such appeal may be made within sixty days of the date on which the order is companymunicated to the Commissioner by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

arguments.claim: ITO District VI had jurisdiction over assessee under s.64(2) by time of appeal due to 1954 residence change.

anchor.surface_text: But the question still remains whether there is any limitation on the power of the Commissioner to numberinate the Income Tax Officer who should file the appeal. One thing seems clear-- from the expression the Income Tax Officer and that is that the Commissioner cannot direct any Income Tax Officer. The expression the Income Tax Officer occurs in various sections of the Act.

arguments.claim: Precedent: In CIT West Bengal v S Sarkar, 'the ITO' points to the one concerned with the case.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the expression denotes an Income Tax Officer having jurisdiction over the assessee or the matter. In other words, the officer selected must have some companycern with the assessee against whom the appeal is filed by the Commissioner of Income Tax. This was also held by the Calcutta High Court in Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. S. Sarkar Co. 1  Chakravarti, C.J. observed in that case To my mind, the definite article the points to the Income Tax Officer who is companycerned with the case at the time when the appeal is to be filed.

arguments.claim: Analogy: In Sardar Baldev Singh, ITO of residence jurisdiction can act under s.34 on assessment by another ITO.

anchor.surface_text: It was held by this Court in Sardar Baldev Singh v. Commis- sioner of Income Tax, Delhi 2  that the Income Tax Officer, Delhi, within whose jurisdiction the resided, companyld initiate proceedings under s. 34 to revise an assessment made by the Income Tax Officer, Lahore, for the assessment year 1944-45.

arguments.claim: Original ITO does not exclusively retain jurisdiction on residence change; concurrent jurisdiction possible, e.g., s.64(4); assessee cannot frustrate by moving.

anchor.surface_text: The reasoning of the High Court for rejecting the companytention of the Department was this Section 5 7  a  gives power to the Commissioner to transfer a case from one officer subordinate to him to another and the Central Board of Revenue can transfer a case from one place to any other place in India. Suppose an assessee resides at a particular place and he has been assessed by the Income tax Officer who has jurisdiction over that area, or is in the process of being assessed.

arguments.claim: Distinction from Punjab HC in R.B.L. Benarsi Dass: Not any ITO can be directed, must have concern with assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dissented from the decision of the Punjab High Court in R. B. L. Benarsi Dass v. C.I.T., East Punjab 1 . The Punjab High Court in that case held that there was numberhing in s. 33 2  to prohibit the Commissioner from directing any Income Tax Officer, other than the one who in fact passed the assessment order, to appeal.

arguments.claim: High Court rightly followed S Sarkar over Punjab case but erred in applying to facts where one ITO assessed but another had residence jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: We companysider that it is number companyrect to say that any Income Tax Officer can be directed to file an appeal. It must be an Income Tax Officer who has companycern with the appeal. The High Court rightly relied on Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. S. Sarkar Co. 2  in dissenting from the view expressed by the Punjab High Court in R. B. L. Benarsi Dass v. C.I.T. East Punjab, 1  but in our view the High Court erred in holding that the facts of the present case are governed by the earlier decision of the Calcutta High Court.

holdings.text: The High Court exceeded its jurisdiction under s. 66 of the Income Tax Act in finding new facts instead of calling for a supplementary statement of the case.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the High Court exceeded its jurisdiction under s. 66 of the Income Tax Act in finding new facts. It it felt any difficulty in answering the question, it should have called for a supplementary statement of the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court looked into records and found new facts not in statement of case; proper procedure under s.66 is to call for supplementary statement.

holdings.text: For the purpose of this appeal, ignore the facts found by the High Court regarding no transfer by Board, subordinations of ITOs, and no transfer to District VI.

anchor.surface_text: We will, for the purpose of this appeal, ignore the following facts found by the High Court  1  that there was numbertransfer of the case by the Board of Revenue  2  that the Income Tax Officer, District 1  2  was an officer subordi- nate to the Commissioner of Income Tax, Calcutta  3  that the Income Tax Officer, District VI, was an officer subordinate to the Commissioner of West Bengal and  4  that there was numbertransfer of the case or the file to the Income Tax Officer, District VI, who was the appropriate officer for the Ballygunge Circular Road area.

holdings.reasoning_summary: These facts were newly found by High Court beyond s.66 jurisdiction; ignore to decide on basis of Tribunal's statement of case.

holdings.text: Under s.33(2), the Commissioner directs 'the Income Tax Officer' who has jurisdiction over the assessee or the matter, not any Income Tax Officer; the ITO performs a ministerial function.

anchor.surface_text: Section 33 2  provides that the Commissioner may, if he objects to any order passed by an Appellate Assistant Commissioner under section 3 1, direct the Income-tax Officer to appeal to the Appellate Tribunal against such order, and such appeal may be made within sixty days of the date on which the order is companymunicated to the Commissioner by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. It is clear from a reading of this subsection that the person who has a right to appeal is the Commis- sioner of Income Tax and number the Income Tax Officer. It would be numbericed that the period of limitation starts from the date on which the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner is companymunicated to the Commissioner by him. It seems to us that, in this companytext, the Income Tax Officer, when he files the appeal under the direction of the Commissioner performs merely a ministerial function. But the question still remains whether there is any limitation on the power of the Commissioner to numberinate the Income Tax Officer who should file the appeal. One thing seems clear-- from the expression the Income Tax Officer and that is that the Commissioner cannot direct any Income Tax Officer. The expression the Income Tax Officer occurs in various sections of the Act. In our view, the expression denotes an Income Tax Officer having jurisdiction over the assessee or the matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'the Income Tax Officer' with definite article; Commissioner nominates ITO with concern/jurisdiction; supported by precedent (S Sarkar).

holdings.text: By 1954, the assessee's change of residence vested jurisdiction over him in the Income Tax Officer, District VI, under s.64(2).

anchor.surface_text: We have already mentioned that the assessee changed his residence to 29B, Ballygunge Circular Road, Calcutta, in 1954. By the time the appeal came to be filed, the Income Tax Officer, District VI, had jurisdiction over him. This follows from sections 64 1  and  2  which read as follows Place of assessment.- 1  Where an assessee carries on a business, profession or vocation at any place, he shall be assessed by the Income-tax Officer of the area in which that place is situate or, where the business, profession or vocation is carried on in more places than one, by the Income-tax Officer of the area in which the principal place of his business, profession or vocation is In all other cases, an assessee shall be assessed by the Income-tax Officer of the area in which he resides.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.64(2) based on residence at time of appeal filing.

holdings.text: The Income Tax Officer who commenced the original assessment does not exclusively retain jurisdiction upon change of assessee's residence under s.64(2); concurrent jurisdiction possible, as in s.64(4), and policy prevents assessee frustrating proceedings by moving.

anchor.surface_text: The reasoning of the High Court for rejecting the companytention of the Department was this Section 5 7  a  gives power to the Commissioner to transfer a case from one officer subordinate to him to another and the Central Board of Revenue can transfer a case from one place to any other place in India. Suppose an assessee resides at a particular place and he has been assessed by the Income tax Officer who has jurisdiction over that area, or is in the process of being assessed. If he changes his residence to another place, then under Section 64  2  the Income, Tax Officer having juris- A.I.R.1954 Cal. 613.  2  40 1. T. R. 605. diction over the new place of residence would acquire jurisdiction. But does that mean that the Income Tax Officer who was proceeding with the original assessment loses his jurisdiction ? If that were so, then an assessee companyld make his assessment impossible by companystantly changing his residence during the assessment. That obviously cannot be the legal position. The legal position is that in such a case, although the officer having jurisdiction over his new place of residence acquires jurisdic- tion under Section 64 2 , the Income-tax Officer who companymenced the original assessment does number lose his jurisdiction to companyplete the case and the companypletion of the case will include the hearing of appeals or revisions against the original order of assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction; policy against abuse; example of concurrent jurisdiction in s.64(4); original ITO retains to complete, but new also acquires.

holdings.text: The Punjab High Court in R.B.L. Benarsi Dass erred; not any Income Tax Officer can be directed under s.33(2), must have concern with assessee; High Court rightly dissented but misapplied to facts.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dissented from the decision of the Punjab High Court in R. B. L. Benarsi Dass v. C.I.T., East Punjab 1 . The Punjab High Court in that case held that there was numberhing in s. 33 2  to prohibit the Commissioner from directing any Income Tax Officer, other than the one who in fact passed the assessment order, to appeal. We companysider that it is number companyrect to say that any Income Tax Officer can be directed to file an appeal. It must be an Income Tax Officer who has companycern with the appeal. The High Court rightly relied on Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. S. Sarkar Co. 2  in dissenting from the view expressed by the Punjab High Court in R. B. L. Benarsi Dass v. C.I.T. East Punjab, 1  but in our view the High Court erred in holding that the facts of the present case are governed by the earlier decision of the Calcutta High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguish facts from Punjab case; follow Calcutta precedent (S Sarkar) but apply differently where residence jurisdiction shifted.

holdings.text: On the facts, the Income Tax Officer, District VI, having jurisdiction over the assessee, could be directed by the Commissioner to file the appeal to the Tribunal; thus, filed by proper person.

anchor.surface_text: In this case, on the facts found by of the Appellate Tribunal, one Income Tax Officer had passed the assessment order while another Income Tax Officer has jurisdiction over the assessee. In our view, the  1  42 I.T.R. 363.  2  A.I.R. 1954 Cal. 613. latter Income Tax Officer having jurisdiction over the assessee companyld be directed by the Commissioner to file the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.33(2) and s.64(2) to facts of residence change; ITO Dist VI had jurisdiction/concern.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly relied on Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal, Calcutta v. S. Sarkar Co. 2  in dissenting from the view expressed by the Punjab High Court in R. B. L. Benarsi Dass v. C.I.T. East Punjab, 1  but in our view the High Court erred in holding that the facts of the present case are governed by the earlier decision of the Calcutta High Court. In this case, on the facts found by of the Appellate Tribunal, one Income Tax Officer had passed the assessment order while another Income Tax Officer has jurisdiction over the assessee. In our view, the

anchor.surface_text: Section 33 2  provides that the Commissioner may, if he objects to any order passed by an Appellate Assistant Commissioner under section 3 1, direct the Income-tax Officer to appeal to the Appellate Tribunal against such order, and such appeal may be made within sixty days of the date on which the order is companymunicated to the Commissioner by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. It is clear from a reading of this subsection that the person who has a right to appeal is the Commis- sioner of Income Tax and number the Income Tax Officer. It would be numbericed that the period of limitation starts from the date on which the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner is companymunicated to the Commissioner by him. It seems to us that, in this companytext, the Income Tax Officer, when he files the appeal under the direction of the Commissioner performs merely a ministerial function. But the question still remains whether there is any limitation on the power of the Commissioner to numberinate the Income Tax Officer who should file the appeal. One thing seems clear-- from the expression the Income Tax Officer and that is that the Commissioner cannot direct any Income Tax Officer. The expression the Income Tax Officer occurs in various sections of the Act. In our view, the expression denotes an Income Tax Officer having jurisdiction over the assessee or the matter.
